title: The Writing's on the Wall II (Year-Long Course)
description: Grounded in humanistic disciplines, this seminar invites students to explore Princeton's campus as a material archive, first introducing them to different modes of textual, visual, and cultural analysis, before guiding them through the writing process as they complete an original research project of their own design.

readings.title: Belonging: A Review of Conceptual Issues, an Integrative Fra
readings.author: Allen, K.-A. et al

readings.title: Buildings for Education
readings.author: Delle Torre, S. et al

readings.title: Master-planning the American Campus: Goals, Actions, and Des
readings.author: Hajrasouliha, A.H.

readings.title: Heritage. Critical Approaches
readings.author: Harrison, R.

prerequisites: This single credit course is a year long. Completion of both semesters is required for credit.  Only students who completed WRI 220 in the fall term are eligible to enroll.
other_information: Spread that fifth course requirement over two semesters instead of one; hone your research and writing skills; take charge of your own research questions. You'll still earn a full EC credit after completing both semesters but neither the fall nor the spring will feel like a heavier load.

title: From Data to Discovery
description: Most of us spend hours of our days reading and learning from the written word. So what makes social scientific methods for textual analysis different from those everyday engagements? And how do scholars transform their raw research discoveries into impactful public-facing products? This seminar will empower sophomores to answer those questions while learning project management skills key to independent work success, expanding their networks on (and beyond!) Princeton's campus, and transforming a genuine personal passion into an intellectually and socially impactful research project.
assignments: Short, weekly assignments will provide students with opportunities to develop, practice, or strengthen research skills relevant to their individual projects and intellectual goals. Those smaller assignments will also be the building blocks of our two summative assignments (a midterm results summary and final project presentation), and they will fuel each semester's concluding exercise about how your research experiences and learning might transfer to other courses and contexts.

readings.author: Oriana Bandiera et al.

readings.author: Kalani Craig et al.

readings.title: You Have to Move!
readings.author: Human Rights Watch

prerequisites: This seminar is a standard, one-semester, full-time course (unlike other Writing Program sophomore research seminars, which operate on a half-time, year-long calendar). WRI 236 is open to all students, whether or not they completed WRI 235 in the fall.
other_information:
Like all sophomore research seminars housed in the Writing Program, this course will include sessions on obtaining undergraduate research funding, building a research network at Princeton (and beyond!), balancing professional ambition with personal wellbeing, cultivating a supportive peer writing community, and sharing research findings effectively in public-facing genres. The enrollment application and waitlist information can be found at: 
https://tinyurl.com/sophsem2526

title: Cuneiform, Codices, Comics II (Year-Long Course)
description: This seminar immerses students in archive-based methods for humanistic inquiry by exploring Special Collections objects (including manuscripts, drawings, death masks, musical scores, among many other items) and empowers them to develop an original research project of their own design.

readings.author: Buch, David J.

prerequisites: This single credit course is a year long. Completion of both semesters is required for credit. Only students who completed WRI 240 in the fall term are eligible to enroll.
other_information: Spread that fifth course requirement over two semesters instead of one; hone your research and writing skills; take charge of your own research questions. You'll still earn a full EC credit after completing both semesters but neither the fall nor the spring will feel like a heavier load.

title: The Invisible Hand II (Year-Long Course)
description: Hands-on engagement with the process of crafting produces a different type of knowledge than that gained via other methods, such as reading a book or making logical deductions about a corpus. This seminar recenters the embodied human in the humanities, inviting students to make the body (all the way down to their own hands!) central to inquiry and discovery. Students design a year-long, hands-on making project, practicing research skills from forming a compelling question to situating insights and connections within their literary, historical, and/or cultural context. Spend a year putting process over product - and make something!
assignments: Short, weekly assignments will provide students with opportunities to develop, practice, or strengthen research skills relevant to their individual projects and intellectual goals. Those smaller assignments will also be the building blocks of each semester's summative assignment and the inspiration for each semester's concluding exercise - about how their research experiences and learning might transfer to other courses and contexts.

prerequisites: This single-credit course is a year long. Completion of both semesters is required for credit. Only students who completed WRI 260 in the fall term are eligible to enroll.
other_information: Like all sophomore research seminars housed in the Writing Program, this course will include sessions on obtaining undergraduate research funding, building a research network at Princeton (and beyond!), balancing professional ambition with personal wellbeing, cultivating a supportive peer writing community, and sharing research findings effectively in public-facing genres.

title: The Curious Scientist II (Year-Long Course)
description: Sure, the latest issue of Nature is filled with thrilling scientific discoveries. But how do researchers dream up these exciting projects? How can undergraduate students move from textbook knowledge into innovative research questions? And what can scientists at all levels do with our findings once we have them? Entry into the world of original STEM research can seem daunting: this seminar will empower sophomores with strategies to develop novel research questions big and small, evaluate and execute methods for answering those questions, and make scientific discoveries more widely accessible.
assignments: Short, weekly assignments will provide students with opportunities to develop, practice, or strengthen research skills relevant to their individual projects and intellectual goals. Those smaller assignments will also be the building blocks of each semester's summative assignment and the inspiration for each semester's concluding exercise about how their research experiences and learning might transfer to other courses and contexts.

readings.title: Brown dwarf in neighboring solar system is actually ...
readings.author: Xuan, J.W.

readings.author: Reardon, D.

readings.title: AI-generated images threaten science
readings.author: Kwon, D.

readings.author: Saguy, A et al

readings.title: Large associative memory problem in neurobiology ...
readings.author: Krotov, D. , Hopfield, J.

prerequisites: This single-credit course redistributes the workload of a single semester over a full year. Completion of both semesters is required to earn that credit. Only students who completed WRI 270 in the fall are eligible to enroll.
other_information: Like all sophomore research seminars housed in the Writing Program, this course will include sessions on obtaining undergraduate research funding, building a research network at Princeton (and beyond!), balancing professional ambition with personal wellbeing, cultivating a supportive peer writing community, and sharing research findings effectively in public-facing genres. The enrollment application and waitlist information can be found at: https://tinyurl.com/sophsem2526

title: Reading & Writing About the Scientific Literature
description: Presentations, conferences, papers, and grants - the work of a scientist is the work of a writer. Academic writing is hard, with additional burdens for students new to academic English. At the same time, large language models can find papers and generate a response at superhuman speed. How might generative AI help, and where does it lead us astray? This course explores how scientific articles are constructed, how research findings are presented, and how scientific arguments are developed. Students learn to read critically and efficiently, differentiate their work from prior research, and cite sources accurately and responsibly.
assignments: For each class, students read research articles and write informal critical responses to exchange with other class members. Students conclude by writing a short literature review relevant to their research project.
prerequisites: This course is open to graduate students in quantitative fields in science, engineering, and social sciences.
other_information: WRI 501 is a full term course and meets once a week for twelve weeks. The course is especially helpful for students who wish to 1) sharpen their critical written analysis in preparation for writing proposals and/or general examinations, 2) engage confidently in conversations about writing with their coauthors and collaborators, and 3) develop a healthy relationship to generative AI.

title: Writing a Grant Proposal in Quantitative Disciplines
description: Graduate work trains us to gather data, but professional researchers often start by gathering funds. In a competitive environment, how can we persuade institutions to choose us? How do we write about research that doesn't yet exist? In this course, students learn to craft concise and compelling grant proposals. Together we will focus on how to start, get unstuck, and alternate between collecting data and composing drafts. By the end of the course, students will have a proposal suitable for submission to departmental committees or external funding agencies such as the NSF, the NIH, the DOD, private foundations, and angel investors.
assignments: Reading sample proposals and writing weekly drafts.
prerequisites: WRI 501 or permission of the instructor.
other_information: WRI 502 is a full term course that meets once a week for twelve weeks. Each class includes opportunities to develop, write, evaluate, and respond to sections of a proposal. Throughout the course, students give and receive feedback on their proposal drafts from each other; they also participate in two individual conferences with the instructor.

title: Writing an Effective Scientific Research Article
description: Writing a scientific research article requires significant support, from guidance on drafting and revision to instruction on appropriate uses of generative AI and more. This course allows students to develop expertise in a genre that requires a systematic format to make a persuasive and novel contribution. Students draft a research article based on their original research, learning: 1) how to use the persuasive aspects of conventional written structure; 2) how to use analysis, feedback, and revision to develop a collaborative writing process; and 3) how to craft concise and compelling arguments that establish new scientific knowledge.
assignments: Every two weeks, students write a new section of a research article on their own work. Reading assignments include examples of published research articles and drafts of articles composed by members of the class.
prerequisites: Course is open to graduate students who have completed sufficient research to begin writing a research article for publication in any area of science, engineering, or quantitative social sciences.  International students require either completion of WRI 501 or permission of the instructor.
other_information: WRI 503 is a full term course that meets once a week for 12 weeks. Each two week period focuses on a different section of the research article. Students also participate in individual conferences with the instructor and a final conference that includes the student's research advisor.

title: Write to Publish (Half-Term)
description: Course guides graduate students in the social sciences and humanities through the process of revising preexisting work into publishable form. Students learn the tricks of publishing and apply proven methods to their own work. In addition to classroom time dedicated to learning specific article-writing skills, participants form an accountability group to help meet milestones in the draft and revision, and have individual conferences for detailed feedback with the course instructor. Scholarship on various aspects of the writing process helps illuminate the many mechanisms behind forming sustainable, positive work habits.
assignments: Students are expected to complete a journal article for submission by the end of the course.

readings.title: Why are some texts good and others not?
readings.author: Beauvais, C.T. Olive, and J.M. Passerault

readings.title: Writing Your Journal Article in Twelve Weeks
readings.author: Belcher, W. L.

readings.title: How to get your article published
readings.author: Dreyfuss, S. and M. Ryan

other_information: This course runs in the Spring term and meets alternating weeks on Fridays for 3 hours (1/30, 2/13, 2/27, 3/20, 4/3, 4/17).  Please visit https://writing.princeton.edu/wri504 for more information on applying to the course.
